oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Coexistence of Two Invasive Species, Procambarus clarkii and Aphanomyces astaci, in Brackish Waters of a Mediterranean Coastal Lagoon
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Martín-Torrijos, Laura
Correa-Villalona, Angel Jose
Pradillo, Antonio
Diéguez-Uribeondo, Javier
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: invasive species
Aphanomyces astaci
Procambarus clarkii
coastal invasion
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p><jats:italic>Procambarus clarkii</jats:italic> is a worldwide freshwater invasive crustacean from North America and was first introduced into Europe the 1970s. Along with <jats:italic>P. clarkii</jats:italic>, another invasive alien species was also spreading: <jats:italic>Aphanomyces astaci</jats:italic>. This pathogen is listed among the 100 World’s worst invasive species and involved in the European native crayfish decline. Although both species live in freshwater ecosystems, <jats:italic>P. clarkii</jats:italic> can withstand brackish waters and inhabit estuarine habitats. However, the presence of <jats:italic>A. astaci</jats:italic> associated to North American crayfishes has never been described in brackish waters. In this study, we have investigated the presence of <jats:italic>A. astaci</jats:italic> in a <jats:italic>P. clarkii</jats:italic> population of a Mediterranean coastal lagoon in the Albufera Natural Park, Valencia, Spain introduced in 1976. Our study confirmed the presence of this pathogen, and suggests that <jats:italic>A. astaci</jats:italic> has been spreading for more than four decades in the mentioned estuarine environment. Mitochondrial ribosomal rnnS and rnnL indicated that the isolated pathogen belongs to d1-haplotype (i.e., D-haplogroup) typically hosted by <jats:italic>P. clarkii</jats:italic>. The presence of this pathogen in a brackish environment may suggest a better adaptation than other <jats:italic>A. astaci</jats:italic> strains to adverse conditions, such as high salinity levels. This is a matter of concern for the conservation of European native freshwater crayfish and highlights once more the risk of introducing invasive alien crustaceans.</jats:p>
